definition[0]: if you give someone, especially a child, a piggyback, you carry them high on your shoulders, supporting them with your hands under their legs
definition[1]: to use something that is bigger, better, or more successful in order to help another product or project succeed
example[0]: videos that piggyback onto the success of proven TV programs
definition[2]: to use someone else’s wi-fi connection to the Internet, without their knowledge or permission
example[1]: How can I prevent other people from piggybacking onto my connection?
definition[3]: to use a situation that already exists in order to do or get what you want
example[2]: Some pharmaceutical companies piggyback on existing brands by borrowing parts of their names.
example[3]: It wants to piggyback its order onto another city’s contract to keep costs down.
definition[4]: to move goods from one place to another, using containers that can be carried both by train and by road
